title: Figma Adds Three AI Image Editing Tools Aimed at Keeping Designers on the Canvas

paragraphs.content: Figma has introduced three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—designed to give designers more precise control over visuals without leaving the app.The tools let users remove unwanted elements, separate and adjust specific subjects, and extend image backgrounds to fit new aspect ratios such as turning a 1:1 product shot into a wide banner.Built to work directly on the Figma canvas, the features are meant to reduce reliance on external editors like Photoshop or Canva for routine tweaks.Figma is also rolling these capabilities into a revamped image editing toolbar that consolidates legacy options like Crop and Remove background with the new tools in a single, contextual interface.

paragraphs.content: A short product video published by Figma demonstrates the new toolbar in action, showing designers isolating objects, erasing distractions, and expanding backgrounds without switching files or tools.Figma positions the update as a way to streamline multi-device asset production, with AI quietly handling repetitive work while humans retain fine-grained control.The company is initially limiting access to users with Full seats on paid plans where AI is enabled, but signals that the image suite will extend to more products across its platform over time.Industry coverage frames the move as part of a broader push to embed assistive AI directly inside creative workflows rather than in standalone generative tools.

sections.title: How Erase, Isolate, and Expand Change Day-to-Day Design Work

paragraphs.content: Figma’s release notes describe the update as “three new AI image editing tools, all centralized in a contextual toolbar,” listing Expand image, Erase object, and Isolate object as the core capabilities.In practice, Erase object lets designers select and remove distracting elements while AI fills in the background so the edit appears seamless, cutting out the need to round-trip assets through external editors for simple cleanups.Isolate object allows a subject—such as a person or product—to be lassoed and then moved or adjusted independently, with controls for lighting, color, focus, and effects that leave the rest of the image intact.Expand image, meanwhile, extends visuals beyond their original borders so teams can adapt a single asset to multiple formats and layouts without heavy manual recomposition.

paragraphs.content: The new tools sit alongside existing functions like Remove background and Crop, giving designers a single, consolidated panel for most common image edits directly on the Figma canvas.Early walkthroughs emphasize that the AI assistance is selection-driven rather than prompt-based, aiming to support precision editing instead of full generative creation.By tightening this loop, Figma is positioning itself less as a handoff point between wireframes and high-fidelity assets and more as a place where production-ready visuals can be refined in context.For teams juggling multiple aspect ratios across web, mobile, and social, the ability to erase clutter, isolate key elements, and expand backgrounds inside a single design file could materially reduce the time spent on repetitive resizing and retouching work.

sections.title: Strategic Positioning in the Competitive AI Design Landscape

paragraphs.content: Commentary around the launch notes that rivals such as Adobe and Canva have offered object removal and background editing for years, framing Figma’s move as both catch-up and a strategic re-centering of image work on its own canvas.Coverage also highlights that Figma’s approach leans on AI without requiring text prompts, distinguishing it from generative image tools and aligning it more closely with day-to-day production tasks for product teams and marketers.Analysts argue that this “assistive, not generative” posture could appeal to organizations wary of introducing prompt-based workflows but eager to speed up asset adaptation and iteration.With Remove background identified as one of the most frequently used actions on the platform, Figma’s decision to anchor it in the redesigned toolbar underscores how central lightweight image manipulation has become to interface and campaign design.

Industry observers say the update could shift more design-stage optimization—like testing different product emphases or ad layouts—into Figma itself, reducing back-and-forth with specialist image editors for every variation.For marketing and growth teams, that may translate into faster A/B testing cycles, as non-specialist collaborators can handle many common edits directly in shared files.At the same time, coverage stresses that high-end compositing and complex retouching will still sit with dedicated tools, casting Figma’s AI features as “good enough” accelerants rather than full replacements for heavyweight suites.As Figma rolls these tools out more broadly across its ecosystem, the company is effectively betting that tightly integrated, context-aware AI will become a baseline expectation inside modern design platforms.
